message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of absent irises and undescended testes suggests the possibility of WAGR syndrome, which is caused by a deletion of chromosome 11 between sites p13 and p14. The renal mass is a common feature of this syndrome, and therefore the most likely cause of this neonate’s symptoms and signs is deletion 11-p-13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of undescended testes suggests a disorder of sex development. The absent irises suggest aniridia. The intra-renal mass suggests Wilms tumor. The most probable genetic disorder is a deletion 11-p-13, which is associated with Wilms tumor and aniridia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of an upper abdominal mass and absent irises and undescended testes suggest the diagnosis of Wilms tumor or nephroblastoma. WT-1 missense mutation is associated with Wilms tumor along with other conditions, but it is not the most likely cause as the question specifies a deletion mutation. Deletion 11-p-13 is the most common genetic abnormality in Wilms tumor and is associated with a higher risk of developing other cancers. Deletion 11-p-15 and duplication of 11-p-15 are not associated with Wilms tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p15.5. WT-1 missense mutations can lead to Wilms tumor, but the presence of absent irises and undescended testes suggests Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome instead. Duplication of 11p15 is not a known genetic disorder, and deletion of 11p13 is not associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a non-tender upper abdominal mass, absent irises, and undescended testes is highly suggestive of WAGR (Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, and mental Retardation) syndrome. This syndrome is caused by a deletion of the 11p13 region, with the WT-1 and PAX6 genes involved. This deletion leads to the development of Wilms tumor, which is most likely the cause of the intra-renal mass seen on MRI. Deletion of 11-p-15 is not associated with any known genetic disorder. Duplication of 11-p-15 is rare, and its clinical significance is unknown.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of irises and undescended testes suggest a diagnosis of WAGR syndrome. Deletion 11-p-13 is associated with this syndrome, which can also cause intra-renal tumors. None of the other options are associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a non-tender upper abdominal mass, absent irises, and undescended testes suggests the patient has WAGR syndrome. WAGR syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p13 that includes the WT-1 gene. Therefore, the most likely genetic disorder in this patient is deletion 11-p-13.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest WAGR syndrome, which is caused by a deletion in chromosome 11p13. The other options are not associated with WAGR syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical findings of an intra-renal mass, absent irises, and undescended testes are suggestive of Wilms tumor, which is associated with deletion of a tumor suppressor gene, WT1, on chromosome 11p13 (option B). None of the other options are associated with Wilms tumor or the specific clinical findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of an intra-renal mass, absent irises, and undescended testes suggest the diagnosis of WAGR syndrome, which is caused by deletion 11-p-13. This syndrome is characterized by Wilms tumor (WT-1), Aniridia (absent irises), Genitourinary anomalies, and mental Retardation.
